title: Getting around
body: To help you tailor the course to your preferences, we've broken the content down into short topics. You're able to filter what you see on the menu and pin the things you find most helpful.
instruction: Select the arrows to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out more.

_items.title: The way you want
_items.body: Use the filter menu at the top left of the page to organise the content on the screen by completion status, bookmarked items or sections of interest.

_items.title: Bookmarking
_items.body: If you find something you like or want to save it for later, you can pin it to your menu by selecting the pin icon. The filter menu at the top left allows you to display pinned items only.

_items.title: Dashboard
_items.body: To help track your progress throughout the topics, in the top right of the screen you will have access to the dashboard. This dashboard is a useful tool that can tell you how you're tracking and will give you guidance on your progress.

_items.title: Resources
_items.body: Use the Resources menu at the top right of the page to explore further resources available in this course.

title: A world of possibilities
body: Whether you're thinking local or global, the Monash Doctoral Program will support your research journey and professional development so you emerge ready to make the greatest possible impact.
instruction: Select Play to hear from our Vice Chancellor.

title: What's in this course
body: Let's take a look at what's involved in completing this course.
instruction: Select each heading to find out more.

_items.title: Straight to the point
_items.body: Each topic has been broken down into small, focused learning bites using video, graphics and web articles. Scroll down the menu page to find the topic you want, then use the navigation arrows to cycle through the learning bites. You can explore the topics in any order, but we suggest you start with 'What is leadership' and work your way through.

_items.title: Want to know more?
_items.body: We've incorporated additional resources to help you develop your leadership skills. These include quick reference guides, documents and web articles with extra insights into leadership. You can access them via the Resources menu at the top right of the page. This reading is estimated to take approximately 30 minutes and can be included in your professional development hours.

_items.title: The next steps
_items.body: We want you to think about how you can build skills for the 21st century – leadership being one of them. That's why this course includes a Leadership Development Plan (LDP). It's a critical component, which once completed, will need to be given to your supervisor for review and sign-off. Download and save the LDP from the Resources menu. We'll refer you to LDP activities throughout this course, which need to be completed offline. It's estimated that these activities will take approximately 90 minutes and can be recorded as part of your professional development hours.

title: What do our graduate researchers say
displayTitle: What do our graduate researchers say
body: How do our graduate researchers define leadership? What role have leadership skills played in their PhD experience and beyond?
instruction: Select Play to find out.

title: What is leadership for you
body: What does leadership mean to you? Before recording your thoughts let’s see what others have to say. Select the arrow to find out more.

Leadership is the art of motivating a group of people to act towards achieving a common goal.

Anon

Leadership is a function of knowing yourself, having a vision that is well communicated, building trust among colleagues, and taking effective action to realise your own leadership potential.

Warren Bennis

All of us must lead if we are to create sustainable change and make our world better.

Barack Obama

Identifying what leadership means to you and others, will help you communicate, influence and lead people around you. It's now time to write down your thoughts.

Download and save your LDP from the Resources menu. In your LDP you'll find the What is leadership for you? activity.

Please take the time to complete that now.

title: Imagine a world without leaders
body: Leaders are invaluable - think of a world with no teachers, no parents, no role models, no coaches, no innovators. Leadership is pervasive, it exists in every part of life, at university, in careers, amongst family and friends, in our communities and even in us.
instruction: Select each heading to find out what a world without leaders might look like.

_items.title: What direction do we take?
_items.body:
Without clear direction it makes it harder or impossible for teams, groups or you to achieve goals.

What do I want to achieve? How will I achieve it? Which path will I take? Is the vision flawed?

Leaders play a big part in looking forward and moving themselves or others in a certain direction.

_items.title: Who will inspire us?
_items.body:
Great! Awesome! Remarkable!

We all benefit from a little motivation, inspiration and encouragement – it could be the leader of a team or your inner voice giving you a pat on the back. Leaders motivate and encourage others to give their best performance all the time.

_items.title: Who will keep us focused?
_items.body: Without focus, organisation and follow through, teams, groups and individuals may find themselves wasting money, time and resources. Leaders help us plan ahead and stay on the track.

_items.title: What about change?
_items.body: Leaders inspire change! Their impact and influence surrounds us every day. It could be the dedicated researcher, the inspiring teacher, the optimistic coach or the risk taking colleague. We need all types of leaders to create impact or change - without them the world would seem a pretty dull place.

title: Think leader. Think you.
body: There's a potential leader in all of us. However, many of us have misconceptions about leadership and our leadership potential. Do any of the common leadership misconceptions below resonate with you?
instruction: Select one or more of the following options and select Submit.

_items.text: I wasn't born to lead.
I don't have any opportunities to develop as a leader.
I'm pretty introverted, I don't see any point in pretending I could be a leader.
Great leaders are in command; they tell everyone what to do.
People don't see me as a leader.
It's not important for me to develop skills not directly relevant to my research.

_feedback.correct: Some of us are too quick to dismiss or discount our own leadership potential. But the truth is that leadership can be earned and learned over time. Everyone has leadership potential and leadership responsibility. Look for, and take on, any leadership opportunities possible – the leadership competencies you develop will help you on campus, at work and in life. Now's it's time to select your LDP from the Resources menu to complete the activity. Think leader. Think you.

_incorrect.final: Some of us are too quick to dismiss or discount our own leadership potential. But the truth is that leadership can be earned and learned over time. Everyone has leadership potential and leadership responsibility. Look for, and take on, any leadership opportunities possible – the leadership competencies you develop will help you on campus, at work and in life. Now's it's time to select your LDP from the Resources menu to complete the activity. Think leader. Think you.

_partlyCorrect.final: Some of us are too quick to dismiss or discount our own leadership potential. But the truth is that leadership can be earned and learned over time. Everyone has leadership potential and leadership responsibility. Look for, and take on, any leadership opportunities possible – the leadership competencies you develop will help you on campus, at work and in life. Now's it's time to select your LDP from the Resources menu to complete the activity. Think leader. Think you.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: What's your leadership experience?
body: Leadership situations may arise with little notice. You might be asked to coach undergraduates, help heal rifts in a team you work with, take the lead amongst a group of motivated researchers, or help deal with challenging group members. Would you know what to do? What's your leadership experience?
disabledBody: You need to measure your confidence in the linked part before you can do this part.
instruction: Select one of the following options and select Submit.

_submit.ariaLabel: Submit your answer by clicking here.

_reset.ariaLabel: Reset the question by clicking here.

_showFeedback.ariaLabel: View the question feedback again by clicking here.

_comparison.lower: Oh you like it less? That's a shame.
_comparison.same: Well, at least you don't like it less.
_comparison.higher: It looks like you're seeing the benefits more and more!

_threshold.text: You don't seem very confident, so it's great that you're completing this course.
It's great that you have some experience in leadership that you can build on! You should take a look at this course and see if it answers some of the questions that you have regarding leadership.
It's great that you have some experience in leadership that you can build on! You should take a look at this course and see if it answers some of the questions that you have regarding leadership.

title: Why learn to lead?
body: The world is demanding different things from leaders. In these times of rapid change and environmental complexity, leadership has taken on a greater importance than ever before.
instruction: Select play to find out more.

title: Leading in the future
body: We live in changing times. An era of disruptive innovation fuelled by the pace of technological advancement, urbanisation, demographic change, sustainability challenges, the economic rise of Asia and other inter-related factors. How will this impact future leaders?
instruction: Select the arrows to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out more.

_items.title: Technological advancements
_items.body: Advanced technologies and continuous innovation will foster an era of collaboration and knowledge sharing. What does this mean for leaders? Leaders will require exceptional collaboration and influencing skills. They'll need to keep up to date with progress in their own fields and in fields they may not fully understand.

_items.title: Changing nature of work
_items.body: Workplaces are changing. Hot-desking and agile workplaces are becoming the norm. Working from home, in the local café, client sites and other locations is now a reality for many people. Leaders need to collaborate with diverse and highly individualised teams. Listening skills and empathy will be vital to identify what motivates others and inspire them to unlock their potential.

_items.title: Digital era
_items.body: Technology has changed how we communicate and work with teams. Software tools and applications on laptops, desktops and mobile devices are increasingly used to collaborate. Leaders will need to engage with diverse individuals with different degrees of digital competence. Also, with the increase of transparency, leaders must display high standards of integrity and sincerity.

title: Be ready to lead
body:
What do all these changes mean for you and your field? For one, you'll need to be ready to collaborate, welcome different points of view, accept ambiguity and create a culture of trust and openness. You'll also need to consider how changes in your field will impact your current research and your future opportunities.

Consider this:

Are mega-trends relating to issues such as urbanisation, an ageing population, digital agriculture or globalisation creating new interest or demand for insights from your research? How could you find out?

Reflect on this and other thought provoking questions. Open your LDP to complete the activity: Be ready to lead.

title: Your leadership matters
body: It's essential that you see yourself as a potential agent of change – not just in contributing new knowledge to help advance your field, but more broadly in society; an individual with valuable skills, insights and competencies that we need to help create a better world.
instruction: Select Play to hear how graduate researchers did just that.

title: Enhance your phd research ride
body: You have the potential to become an important agent of change. Taking on leadership activities will not only develop your skills, but allow you to embrace opportunities to deliver change.
instruction: Select the arrows to find out what steps you can take.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out what steps you can take.

_items.title: Collaborate and share
_items.body: Look for opportunities to collaborate. Take on student leadership roles and identify change opportunities, (e.g. club / society committee member, festival director, debate committee member, magazine editor). Liaise with individuals or organisations involved in your doctoral research to identify areas of improvement. (e.g. community groups, government, landholders, industry, households, educators, etc.)

_items.title: Keep up the good work
_items.body: Take on roles that allow you to gain valuable insights and spot new opportunities for growth. Work as a research assistant. Be a tutor to undergraduate and masters students. Volunteer your time with not-for-profit organisations (e.g. social or environmental organisations, international or local organisations). Look for part-time work in industry.

_items.title: Share your thoughts
_items.body: Change is about shifting people's thinking. Speak or engage at research-related conferences and forums (e.g. conferences, presenting papers, research groups). Disseminate research findings and insights via various communication channels (e.g. articles in peer reviewed journals, magazines, blogs, formal and informal presentations, panel discussions).

_items.title: Think bigger than today
_items.body: Think about the entrepreneurial opportunities arising from doctoral research. Join incubator/entrepreneurship programs. You've got to think beyond now and even beyond the most immediate future. What will you do as a post-doctorate in society? What career will be most rewarding?

title: Impact the future
body: In unleashing your potential where might you find yourself? Developing professional skills, such as leadership, will help you make the greatest possible impact whatever your discipline and vision. Let's see the impact these Monash PhD graduates are making.
instruction: Select each heading to find out.

_items.title: Law
_items.body: Dr Noel Villaroman works for the UN, providing advice on international legal protection of ethnic and religious minorities. His training as a PhD in Law researcher at Monash equipped him with the knowledge and skills required for his current job. He believes that more than anything else, patience, diligence, thoroughness and precision traits that he honed during his PhD candidature, are proving to be of great use in the real world.

_items.title: Medicine
_items.body: Dr Hannah Kirk completed a PhD at the Faculty of Medicine, Nursing and Health Sciences. During her PhD, Hannah (in collaboration with her supervisor Professor Kim Cornish) created a gaming technology known as the TALI Attention Training Program, which assists children with developmental disabilities. After completing her PhD, Hannah was appointed the Chief Research Officer at Avexa Limited, a medtech company that acquired the TALI technology that Hannah created.

_items.title: Science
_items.body: Dr Nurin Veis completed a PhD at the Faculty of Science in Biochemistry. She is regarded as one of the world's leading curators of human biology and medicine. She is now the Manager of Scienceworks (Museum Victoria).

_items.title: Engineering
_items.body: Dr Daniel Edgington-Mitchell was awarded his PhD from Monash University in 2013. He now works as an academic in the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering at Monash University, and nurtures the next generation of researchers.

_items.title: Education
_items.body: Professor Greg Leigh AO completed his PhD at the Faculty of Education in 1995. He now runs the Renwick Centre (what was the Royal Institute for Deaf and Blind Children). He has an order of Australia and has made significant contributions to education of those with a sensory impairment in Australia.

title: What do we want?
body: What do people expect from their leaders? Effective communication, active listening, interpersonal skills, empowerment? Let's hear what some of our graduate researchers want from their leaders?
instruction: Select play to find out.

title: What matters to you?
body: What do you believe the characteristics of a good leader are? What type of leader do you want to be?  Successful leaders demonstrate particular skills and attributes. Which of these are important to you?
instruction: Select one or more from the following options and select submit.

_items.text: Being honest
Coaching, mentoring, role modelling
Being flexible in approach
Making decisions and solving problems
Caring about people
Competent
Forward-looking

_feedback.correct: While leadership is easy to explain, leadership is not so easy to practice. Few people are born to be leaders. Most of us need to practise being a good leader. That's why taking the time to identify leadership qualities and skills is an important step in your leadership development. Select the What makes a successful leader? document and 'The most important leadership competencies' article from the Resources menu. These delve more into key leadership skills and attributes.

_incorrect.final: While leadership is easy to explain, leadership is not so easy to practice. Few people are born to be leaders. Most of us need to practise being a good leader. That's why taking the time to identify leadership qualities and skills is an important step in your leadership development. Select the What makes a successful leader? document and 'The most important leadership competencies' article from the Resources menu. These delve more into key leadership skills and attributes.

_partlyCorrect.final: While leadership is easy to explain, leadership is not so easy to practice. Few people are born to be leaders. Most of us need to practise being a good leader. That's why taking the time to identify leadership qualities and skills is an important step in your leadership development. Select the What makes a successful leader? document and 'The most important leadership competencies' article from the Resources menu. These delve more into key leadership skills and attributes.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: How to lead
body: So what do the experts think? A synthesis of leadership literature suggests that there are some core characteristics that are found in good leaders. These qualities can be developed or may be naturally part of their personality.
instruction: Select each heading to find out more.

_items.title: Core values and clear vision
_items.body: Leaders have a set of core values aligned with their own or organisation's vison. Great leaders display both their values and their ethics in their leadership approach and actions. They ensure their vision and direction is one that other people want to share and follow.

_items.title: Pro-social behaviour
_items.body: Leaders are concerned with the rights, feelings and needs of others; they believe people are important. They co-operate with others to achieve goals and assist people in developing to their full potential. Integrity is key to their success. They embody honesty, effort, reliability and humility when collaborating and communicating with others.

_items.title: Inspire others
_items.body: They inspire others to achieve common goals. How? Enthusiasm, passion, communication and confidence. Leaders who convey confidence, dedication and integrity motivate and encourage the best efforts from team members, colleagues, friends or family.

_items.title: Resilience
_items.body: People look to leaders in time of crisis or uncertainty. Good leaders show a high resilience to obstacles and stress. They are optimistic and portray confidence and a positive demeanour. They remain level-headed and composed and lead people to a solution.

_items.title: Creative and innovative
_items.body: Good leaders develop creative and innovative solutions; they challenge the status quo. They anticipate trends, take risks and explore opportunities in the achievement of goals. They also collaborate with others and provide opportunities for them to express ideas.

_items.title: Good decision makers
_items.body: Often leaders must make tough decisions; decisions that require a firmness, authority, and finality that will not please everyone. Good leaders make decisions based on logic and fact and gain the confidence of others. They also know when it's important to foster collaborative decision making.

title: The key to leading
body:
While some people seem to have a natural tendency to leadership qualities, it does not mean that they will be good leaders, or that others will be lessor leaders.

Good leaders are followed because people trust and respect them, rather than because of specific skills they possess. It’s time to identify a leader who inspires you. Select your LDP from the Resources menu to complete the activity: The key to leading.

title: What do the experts say?
body: Leadership is quite complex. Behaviours, personality, influence, ethics and situation all play some part in how leadership is defined and practised.
instruction: Select Play to find out more.

title: Get to know the theory
body: So, what makes the leader stand apart from the crowd? Is it their characteristics and behaviours? Is it their leadership style? Is it based on the relationships they form? What does the theory tell us?
instruction: Select the icons to find out about each leadership theory.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out about each leadership theory.

_items.title: 'Great man'
_items.body: Have you ever heard someone being described as a 'born leader'? The 'Great Man' theory assumes that leaders are born with innate qualities and are destined to lead. The term 'man' was intentional, since at that time, leadership was a concept that was primarily male, military and Western.

_items.title: Trait
_items.body: Successful leaders exhibit specific traits -  they're born with extraversion, integrity and courage. The lists of traits are many and continue to be produced. They draw on virtually all the adjectives in the dictionary, which describe some positive or virtuous human attribute, from ambition to zest for life.

_items.title: Behavioural
_items.body: Leaders are made, not born – they can learn leadership through teaching and observation. This theory concentrates on what leaders actually do rather than on their traits or source of power. Different patterns of behaviour are observed and categorised as 'styles of leadership'.

_items.title: Situational
_items.body: Which leadership style does the situation call for? Situational theories propose that leaders choose the best course of action based on the situation at hand. This means not one leadership style is suitable in all situations. Whilst some situations may require an autocratic style, others may need a more participative approach.

_items.title: Contingency
_items.body: It's not just about your leadership style! Effective leadership is contingent or dependent on various other situational factors. The leader's capabilities, personality and preferred leadership style, along with the behaviours of followers, all play a part in the leader's success.

_items.title: Transactional
_items.body: Transactional theories focus on the relationship between leader and followers. It assumes there's a form of 'contract' in place, where the leader issues the assigned work, praises or criticises, rewards or punishes the followers for their commitment, work and loyalty.

_items.title: Transformational
_items.body: It's all about change. Leaders inspire others to follow, support and be part of a vision. Tasks and work are flexible and followers take responsibility for new ideas. Passion, enthusiasm and energy are key to the leaders' success. People follow because of their connection to the leader and the vision, not because they have to.

title: Transformational or transactional leadership?
body: Is one better than the other? In this modern age, a leader is someone that energises people to action, develops followers into leaders, and transforms others into agents of change. Let's look into transformational leadership in more detail. How does it differ from transactional leadership?
instruction: Consider the statements below. Select the leadership theory it represents and select Submit.

_items.text: Responsive leadership that mainly deals with present issues.
Leaders create learning opportunities to stimulate followers to solve problems.
It relies on a mutually beneficial relationship.
Motivates followers by encouraging them to put group interests first.
Preoccupied with purposes and values, morals, and ethics.

_feedback.correct: That's right. Transactional leadership involves exchanging rewards for loyalty and performance. Transformational leadership works on building trust and increasing motivation. Rather than elevating one particular theory over another, researchers talk of the need for an integrative approach. Select Leadership theories from the Resources menu. This article provides you with further insight into each of the theories. Then visit your LDP to complete the activity: Making sense of leadership theory.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. Transactional leadership involves exchanging rewards for loyalty and performance. Transformational leadership works on building trust and increasing motivation. Rather than elevating one particular theory over another, researchers talk of the need for an integrative approach. Select Leadership theories from the Resources menu. This article provides you with further insight into each of the theories. Then visit your LDP to complete the activity: Making sense of leadership theory.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. Transactional leadership involves exchanging rewards for loyalty and performance. Transformational leadership works on building trust and increasing motivation. Rather than elevating one particular theory over another, researchers talk of the need for an integrative approach. Select Leadership theories from the Resources menu. This article provides you with further insight into each of the theories. Then visit your LDP to complete the activity: Making sense of leadership theory.

title: See styles in action
body: How do people approach leadership situations? It all depends on the circumstances, position, beliefs, preferences and values of the people involved. Let's see the coaching style in action.
instruction: Select play.

title: Explore the choices
body: Leading a team? Coaching a sports team? Trying to influence a peer? Whatever the situation, understanding leadership styles and their impact, can help you get the right results. There are many different models of leadership styles, from those that look at how much 'control' you want to others based around 'potential'. One of the best-known models is Daniel Goleman's Six Leadership Styles.
instruction: Select each heading to learn more about each style.

_items.title: Coercive – "Do what I tell you"
_items.body: Leaders show initiative, self-control and demand immediate obedience. Is there a time and a place for such leadership? It's most effective in times of crisis, such as in a company turnaround, or during an actual emergency. It can also help control a problem team member, when everything else has failed. It doesn't encourage initiative, and often has a negative effect on how people feel.

_items.title: Pacesetting - "Do as I do now"
_items.body: Leaders expect and model excellence and self-direction. They lead by example, show initiative and conscientiousness, and ask the same from everyone. Works well with a highly-competent and well-motivated team, and when quick results are the goal. What are the consequences? It can decrease team morale – as people feel restricted and overwhelmed by the leader's demands for excellence.

_items.title: Authoritative – "Come with me"
_items.body: Leaders are high in self-confidence and empathy. They act as a change catalyst by drawing people into the vision and engaging them with the future. Promotes innovation and allows people to experiment and take calculated risks. It works best when teams need a new vision or clear direction. It's not the best fit when the leader is working with a team of experts who know more than them.

_items.title: Affiliative – "People come first"
_items.body: Leaders value and create emotional bonds and harmony. They demonstrate empathy, strong communication skills, and are very good at building relationships. Works best in times of stress, when teams need to heal from a difficult experience, or need to rebuild trust. What about the team goals? It's not very goal-oriented, so using it for a long period of time won't necessarily 'get the job done'.

_items.title: Democratic – "What do you think?"
_items.body: Leaders build consensus through participation. They show high levels of collaboration, team leadership and strong communication skills. Most effective when the leader needs the team to own and buy into a decision, plan, or project. It's not the best choice in an emergency situation, as it takes quite a bit of time for momentum to build and the team to reach a consensus.

_items.title: Coaching – "Try this"
_items.body: Leaders develop people. They allow people to try different approaches to problem solving and achieving a goal. They show high levels of empathy, self-awareness and skills in developing others. It's useful when employees show initiative and an organisation values long-term staff development. It may not work well if people are defiant and unwilling to change or learn, or if the leader lacks proficiency.

title: Make the call
body: Successful leaders adapt and adjust their leadership style to suit the situation, the people and the outcome they're looking for. Will you be able to lead the way and make the right call? Reflect on the situations below and choose the leadership style you feel will be most appropriate and deliver the best results.
instruction: Select your response from the options below and select Submit.

_items.text: The research team is competent, but the deadline is looming and you need them to step it up a notch.
You would like to implement a new research direction and convince the team to follow your lead.
The team isn't collaborating. Everyone seems to be doing their own thing and internal rifts are popping up.
You're starting a new project. Your team is experienced and you're trying to get them to come up with fresh ideas.

_feedback.correct: That's right. You seem to have a grip on the leadership styles and their use. Effective leaders adopt and exhibit many styles, particularly the authoritative, democratic, affiliative and coaching styles - as they have an overall positive impact on climate and performance. Select the 'Leadership that gets results' article from the Resources menu to learn more about Goleman's leadership style framework.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. Pacesetting works well if you would like to get quick results from a highly motivated and competent team. Changing team direction is best suited to an authoritative approach. The affiliative style helps to heal rifts in a team or to motivate people during stressful circumstances. The democratic approach draws on people's knowledge and skills, and creates a group commitment to the resulting goals. Select the 'Leadership that gets results' article from the Resources menu to learn more about Goleman's leadership style framework.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. Pacesetting works well if you would like to get quick results from a highly motivated and competent team. Changing team direction is best suited to an authoritative approach. The affiliative style helps to heal rifts in a team or to motivate people during stressful circumstances. The democratic approach draws on people's knowledge and skills, and creates a group commitment to the resulting goals. Select the 'Leadership that gets results' article from the Resources menu to learn more about Goleman's leadership style framework.

title: Leverage the differences
body: Understanding different personalities, perspectives and motivations (including your own), is at the heart of learning to lead, and choosing the appropriate leadership style. The most effective leaders don't use just one leadership style, they're able to move between styles, choosing the one that best suits the situation. They're responsive; they adapt by leveraging different qualities to drive their teams forward and gain a positive outcome.
instruction: Select Play to learn more.

title: The keys to emotional intelligence
body: So how do leaders show emotional intelligence? Can they manage themselves and their relationships effectively? When under stress, do they lose control, or do they calmly assess the situation? Overcoming stress, identifying and reacting well to emotions, and being aware of how you impact others is described as emotional intelligence.
instruction: Select each heading to find out more.

_items.title: Self-awareness
_items.body: Self-awareness is the ability to recognise your own emotions and values and how they impact others. Do you have a strong and positive sense of self-worth? Do you take the time to reflect on why you make certain decisions? Do you evaluate your strengths and limitations? People with a strong understanding of who they are and what they want to work on, show high emotional intelligence.

_items.title: Self-management
_items.body: What are the keys to self-management? Great leaders practise self-control; they think before they act. They control or redirect disruptive emotions and adapt to changing situations. They work to keep the team moving in a positive direction by being trustworthy, conscientious and ready to seize opportunities. People with a strong sense of commitment and personal accountability, can create a unified and positive team culture.

_items.title: Social awareness
_items.body: Empathy is key! People who show social awareness take the time to understand the wants, needs, and viewpoints of those around them. Building social awareness involves taking an active interest in what others have to say, removing judgements and stereotypes and improving personal connections. Positive and productive relationships and networks are the result.

_items.title: Social skill
_items.body: We all want a leader who can manage conflict, communicate well and help others develop and shine. Leaders who excel in social skills are good at handling other people's emotions. They collaborate with others and think beyond their own success. They inspire a shared direction and vision, initiate new ideas and influence others to follow their lead.

title: Eyes open!
body: Emotional intelligence is a skill that can be developed. Those who lack emotional intelligence simply need to become more aware of their emotions and the emotions of others. They also need to learn how to pick up on signs or cues and respond to them effectively.
instruction: Select Play.

title: How did Janice go?
body: What levels of emotional intelligence were used? It seems there were things that Janice could've have improved on. What went wrong?
instruction: What levels of emotional intelligence were used? It seems there were things that Janice could've have improved on. What went wrong?

_items.text: Used incorrect name
Openly talked about fudging the research data
Failed to notice how her research impacted others
Referred to her notes often
Focused on negative impacts

_feedback.correct: That's right. Janice showed a lack of emotional intelligence. She did not show a solid understanding of how her opinions and actions affected the other person. She also lacked confidence and was openly dishonest. Emotional intelligence is a powerful tool. It can help you improve relationships, achieve your goals and create a productive and positive working environment. What can you do to improve yours? Select your LDP from the Resources menu to complete the activity: Build your emotional intelligence.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. Janice showed a lack of emotional intelligence. She did not show a solid understanding of how her opinions and actions affected the other person. She also lacked confidence and was openly dishonest. Emotional intelligence is a powerful tool. It can help you improve relationships, achieve your goals and create a productive and positive working environment. What can you do to improve yours? Select your LDP from the Resources menu to complete the activity: Build your emotional intelligence.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. Janice showed a lack of emotional intelligence. She did not show a solid understanding of how her opinions and actions affected the other person. She also lacked confidence and was openly dishonest. Emotional intelligence is a powerful tool. It can help you improve relationships, achieve your goals and create a productive and positive working environment. What can you do to improve yours? Select your LDP from the Resources menu to complete the activity: Build your emotional intelligence.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: The two roles
body: Managers work mainly with processes, models and systems and manage others to do the job well. Leaders focus on where a team is headed, what their vision should be and motivating and empowering people to achieve it.
instruction: Select Play to find out more.

title: What's the difference?
body: Managers and leaders use different styles to motivate people to achieve short and long-term objectives. Leaders have followers, people who follow them voluntarily. Managers have subordinates, people who work for them. Taking the time to think about what it means to manage, and what it means to lead, can help us be better at both.
instruction: Select the arrows to find out the key differences.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out the key differences.

_items.title: The manager...
_items.body:
• Administers
  • Maintains
  • Focuses on systems and structure
  • Controls systems and people
  • Accepts the status quo
  • Has a short-term view
  • Manages tasks

_items.title: The leader...
_items.body:
• Innovates
  • Develops
  • Focuses on people and emotions
  • Inspires people
  • Challenges the status quo
  • Has a long-term perspective

title: Do managers lead?
body: Are all managers leaders? Are all leaders managers? Is a good manager automatically a good leader? Reflect on the statements below and select which of the following you believe to be true regarding leadership and management.
instruction: Select one or more of the following options and select Submit.

_items.text: Management and leadership are not mutually exclusive.
Most managers never need to act as leaders.
Leadership is not only a characteristic of people who hold positions of authority.
Good leaders are always bad managers.
Leaders are often more comfortable with risk.
It's not possible to be a leader unless you have formal management responsibilities.
To be a leader, you need to have followers.
Followers never become leaders.

_feedback.correct: That's right. It's possible to be both a manager and a leader, and sometimes both at the same time. Sometimes you need to ensure that you're managing goals, and other times, you're setting new goals and inspiring new ways of thinking. It's also possible to be a leader even when you have no formal management responsibilities. The key distinction is in whether you have followers, people who have chosen to follow your lead. Select the article 'Managers and Leaders: Are they Different?' from the Resources tab to explore the potential differences in more detail.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. It's possible to be both a manager and a leader, and sometimes both at the same time. Sometimes you need to ensure that you're managing goals, and other times, you're setting new goals and inspiring new ways of thinking. It's also possible to be a leader even when you have no formal management responsibilities. The key distinction is in whether you have followers, people who have chosen to follow your lead. Select the article 'Managers and Leaders: Are they Different?' from the Resources tab to explore the potential differences in more detail.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. It's possible to be both a manager and a leader, and sometimes both at the same time. Sometimes you need to ensure that you're managing goals, and other times, you're setting new goals and inspiring new ways of thinking. It's also possible to be a leader even when you have no formal management responsibilities. The key distinction is in whether you have followers, people who have chosen to follow your lead. Select the article 'Managers and Leaders: Are they Different?' from the Resources tab to explore the potential differences in more detail.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: What sort of leader are you?
displayTitle: What sort of leader are you?
body: Which of the six styles do you tend to use? Are these styles well suited to the challenges you face? How might you improve your effectiveness as a leader?
instruction: Select each heading to find out how to develop your leadership profile.

_items.title: What's your default style?
_items.body: First, reflect on what kind of leader you are naturally. Stop and think how you try to influence people around you. Are you predominantly a coercive leader, adopting the "my way is best" approach? Or perhaps more of a coaching leader, encouraging people to "try this"? Maybe you're more authoritative, working to ensure everyone's on the same page, "let's consider why we need to change direction".

_items.title: Develop your style
_items.body: Next, consider how you can shape up your leadership form. Everyone can improve on their default style and develop alternative styles. It takes a combination of self-awareness, self-discipline and action. Work on developing the styles you're least sure of. Watch others whose style you would like to learn. Seek feedback from peers, supervisors or friends about your approach.

_items.title: Change it up
_items.body: Remember, there's no perfect leadership style. Some will be better suited to particular situations; however, one style will not work in all situations. Each person you lead will have different needs and their own unique style. How do you get the best results? Be the right leader, at the right time. Adapt your style to reflect the situation, the people and the result you're after.

title: The team's dilemma
body: What causes conflict in a team? It may be individual differences, personality clashes, poor communication or differing goals. Different people think about the same things in a different way, have different skills and styles and may want totally different things.
instruction: Select Play to see the team's dilemma.

title: Which style will work?
body: You don't agree with Charlie's decision or approach. However, you need to reach a consensus and make a decision on how the team will proceed. What steps would you take?
instruction: Select one or more of the following options and select Submit.

_items.text: Try to understand his point of view.
Give in to his suggestion.
State your opinions and goals again.
Fight back and demand compliance.
Change the subject.
Look for mutual goals.

_feedback.correct: That's right. Any time you bring people together to solve a problem or make a decision you may end up with a conflict. Conflict is only negative if it's not resolved or properly managed. A leader must be able to negotiate and assist people to come to agreement. This requires assertiveness and a balanced emotionally intelligent approach to handling conflict.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. Any time you bring people together to solve a problem or make a decision you may end up with a conflict. Conflict is only negative if it's not resolved or properly managed. This is not a crisis, there's no need to fight back, it may trigger further conflict. Also, avoiding the situation by changing the subject or giving in undermines your position as a leader and the issue will remain unresolved. A leader must be able to negotiate and assist people to come to agreement. This requires assertiveness and a balanced emotionally intelligent approach to handling conflict.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. Any time you bring people together to solve a problem or make a decision you may end up with a conflict. Conflict is only negative if it's not resolved or properly managed. This is not a crisis, there's no need to fight back, it may trigger further conflict. Also, avoiding the situation by changing the subject or giving in undermines your position as a leader and the issue will remain unresolved. A leader must be able to negotiate and assist people to come to agreement. This requires assertiveness and a balanced emotionally intelligent approach to handling conflict.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: Work on the styles
body:
It's important when faced with certain situations, that you're ready to deal with it. Versatility – your ability to adapt, using diverse styles in various situations with different people – is key to your success.

If you're naturally a democratic or affiliative leader, how will you take command or swift action in a crisis? You'll need to find a way to adopt the coercive style in a way that feels true to you, perhaps by injecting some humour into your orders. Once you've grasped the key skills for each style, you should be in a good position to start to put the new leadership style into practice. To learn more select the Developing leadership styles guide from the Resources menu.

Time to think about your own leadership style. Visit your LDP to complete the activity: Develop your style.

title: Personal power
body: Personal power is more an attitude or state of mind than an attempt to manoeuvre or control others. It's based on competence, vision and positive personal qualities.
instruction: Select Play to hear how building your personal power can make the difference.

title: Get results
body: Personal power is a core leadership competency that everyone needs to develop before they can lead others. One of the key elements of influencing and using your personal power is credibility. How can you establish your credibility as a leader and start to get the results you want?
instruction: Select the headings to find out more.

_items.title: Be clear
_items.body: Do you have a clear sense of where you're going and what you want to achieve? Can you describe it to others? People with high levels of personal power are clear and focused on what is important. They have clear goals and take deliberate action.

_items.title: Walk your talk
_items.body: Do you deliver what you promise? Do your actions speak louder than words? Credibility is earned through honesty, integrity, reliability and practising what you preach. Credible leaders take full responsibility for their actions and decisions, are transparent with their actions and foster an honest environment where unethical behaviour isn't tolerated.

_items.title: Communicate well
_items.body: Communication builds a bridge between people. Leaders are great communicators that make others feel they are being heard, attended to, consulted and valued. Ask questions to show interest in what others have to say. Actively listen, seek first to understand, then to be understood.

_items.title: Generate enthusiasm
_items.body: Want to motivate and influence others? Use energy and enthusiasm. Find out what energises other people around you; once you understand this, you can adapt the way you work with them and they're likely to be more energised and motivated to work with you.

title: Reap the rewards
body: What leadership situations, opportunities or challenges do you face? Are you leading people as part of your research? Are you working with others to get tasks done or deliver particular outcomes? Are you inspiring or motivating others by the findings of your work? Reflect on the importance of personal power. What could you do to harness your personal power and reap the rewards.
instruction: Select one or more of the following options and select Submit.

_items.text: Develop solutions to problem and situations you're faced with.
Include others in decision-making processes.
Communicate assertively.
Support others while they do important work.
Offer and receive encouragement and reinforcement.
Continually expand your knowledge and expertise.

_feedback.correct: That's right. These activities will help you establish credibility, as well as help you in your journey of learning to lead. You don't always need formal authority to lead. In fact, respect is earned mostly from personal sources of power. Personal power transfers from your personality, learning, experience and abilities. Building your personal power is a process. It involves time, effort, and patience, but it's totally worth investing in for successful leadership. Visit your LDP to complete the activity: Make an immediate impact.

_incorrect.final: That's not right. All these activities will help you establish credibility, as well as help you in your journey of learning to lead. You don't always need formal authority to lead. In fact, respect is earned mostly from personal sources of power. Personal power transfers from your personality, learning, experience and abilities. Building your personal power is a process. It involves time, effort, and patience, but it's totally worth investing in for successful leadership. Visit your LDP to complete the activity: Make an immediate impact.

_partlyCorrect.final: That's not quite right. All these activities will help you establish credibility, as well as help you in your journey of learning to lead. You don't always need formal authority to lead. In fact, respect is earned mostly from personal sources of power. Personal power transfers from your personality, learning, experience and abilities. Building your personal power is a process. It involves time, effort, and patience, but it's totally worth investing in for successful leadership. Visit your LDP to complete the activity: Make an immediate impact.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: Welcome the opportunities
body: Let's hear how some of our graduate researchers took the leadership challenge and developed their leadership skills.
instruction: Select Play.

title: Learning to lead
body: Learning to lead is a lifelong journey. Good leaders never stop learning. So what can you do to continue learning to lead?
instruction: Select the arrows to find out more.
mobileInstruction: Select the arrows and then the plus icons to find out more.

_items.title: Experience matters
_items.body: In learning to lead nothing beats experience, including learning from your mistakes. Take the opportunity to learn new things by putting yourself in leadership situations. For example, run a PhD group, be a research assistant, tutor undergraduate students or take on part-time employment.

_items.title: Learn from others
_items.body:
Learn about leadership from people around you. Here are some tips:
  • Read books by recognised leadership experts.
  • Read biographies or autobiographies about leaders you admire.
  • Source articles on leadership, as well as academic literature specific to your field.
  • Watch videos and clips by inspiring or effective leaders.
  • Spend time with people who are experienced leaders (within academia or elsewhere).
  • Think about who could help as a mentor or coach for you.

_items.title: Extend your network
_items.body: It's worth thinking about and creating a simple stakeholder map. A map of people you know, or who might be useful to know, given your research and ambitions for the future. These might be people or groups you might want to manage closely, keep informed, keep satisfied, or just monitor.

title: Take the leadership challenge
body:
How can you become a better leader? Commit to continually learning to lead. Take on leadership challenges and commit to practising your skills. This might include becoming a better speaker, building stronger relationships or taking yourself out of your comfort zone.

For example, building and growing your relationships will help you become a better leader. The more connected you are, the more people you have to collaborate and share feedback with, the better off you'll be.

What steps will you take? Visit your LDP to complete the activity: Take the leadership challenge.

title: Developing your plan
body: Research conducted by Nick Petrie from the Centre for Creative Leadership (CCL) suggests that there are five important steps required to ensure that you apply the learning from a leadership development program.
instruction: Select each heading to find out more.

_items.title: Make achievable commitments
_items.body: Rather than over-committing, identify two or three realistic commitments about what you can do to improve your leadership performance. For example, "I will not avoid having difficult conversations with my colleagues or supervisors, when I believe an important issue needs to be discussed."

_items.title: Share your commitments
_items.body: People are more likely to live up to their commitments if they share them with other people. Identify people who can help you and share your leadership commitments with them. You may also wish to share your commitments with a broader audience.

_items.title: Seek feed forward suggestions
_items.body: Feed-forward is a process where people provide positive suggestions about how you can work towards achieving a goal or commitment. Think about how you can achieve your commitments or ask others to provide you with ideas.

_items.title: Make your commitments visible
_items.body: Write your commitments down, make them visible (to yourself and others). You could use coloured pens, pictures or postcard images – anything that will serve as a visual daily reminder of your commitments.

_items.title: Identify clear actions
_items.body: Once you are clear about your commitments, identify the action steps you can take to achieve them. The actions that you develop may have been areas you have self-identified or may come from the feed-forward suggestions you received from others.

title: PLAN FOR THE PRESENT. PREPARE FOR THE FUTURE.
displayTitle: PLAN FOR THE PRESENT. PREPARE FOR THE FUTURE.
body: Developing your leadership capabilities will help enhance your research and prepare you for life after your degree. Ask yourself, "What do I need to work on to be a better leader"?
instruction: Select one or more of the following options and select Submit.

_items.text: Build my leadership confidence.
Build my emotional intelligence.
Develop my leadership style.
Develop alternative leadership styles.
Improve my motivation skills.
Build my personal power.

_feedback.correct: All of these are correct, and these are just a few suggestions. Take the time to identify what you would like to work on to become a better leader. Identify a set of clear actions that you can take, in order to achieve your commitments. For example, you may want to build your leadership confidence by running a PhD group. Time to make the commitment! Open your LDP to complete your LDP action plan. Discuss your plan with your supervisor, mentor, coach or industry expert and find out how they can help you implement your development plan.

_incorrect.final: All of these are correct, and these are just a few suggestions. Take the time to identify what you would like to work on to become a better leader. Identify a set of clear actions that you can take, in order to achieve your commitments. For example, you may want to build your leadership confidence by running a PhD group. Time to make the commitment! Open your LDP to complete your LDP action plan. Discuss your plan with your supervisor, mentor, coach or industry expert and find out how they can help you implement your development plan.

_partlyCorrect.final: All of these are correct, and these are just a few suggestions. Take the time to identify what you would like to work on to become a better leader. Identify a set of clear actions that you can take, in order to achieve your commitments. For example, you may want to build your leadership confidence by running a PhD group. Time to make the commitment! Open your LDP to complete your LDP action plan. Discuss your plan with your supervisor, mentor, coach or industry expert and find out how they can help you implement your development plan.

_submit.ariaLabel: Select here to submit your answer.

title: It's all up to you
body: In today's world, career paths are becoming more flexible and diverse and new opportunities are appearing. Be prepared to take advantage of such opportunities by developing your leadership skills. It's a critical factor in your career success. Let's hear how developing leadership skills made all the difference.
instruction: Select Play.
